tit.e: Koseki, a family register of the Imperial Family.
Koseki, a family register of the Imperial Family.
Koseki, a family register of the Imperial Family.

sen.j: 皇籍（こうせき）とは、皇族の一員たる籍・資格をいう。
sen.e: Koseki refers to a family register or eligibility to be a member of the Imperial family.
Koseki refers to a family register or eligibility to be a member of the Imperial Family.
sen.cmt: family → Family に訂正しました。
sen.e: Koseki refers to a family register or eligibility to be a member of the Imperial Family.

sen.j: 対義語は臣民籍あるいは臣籍（しんせき）で、臣民（国民）としての籍の意。
sen.e: Status of a subject (known as Shinminseki or Shinseki, antonyms of Koseki) represent a status as a Japanese subject, Shinmin (Kokumin)
The antonym of Koseki is Shinminseki or Shinseki, which mean a status of a subject.
sen.cmt: 訳がわかりにくかったため、大幅に変更しました。
sen.e: The antonym of Koseki is Shinminseki or Shinseki, which mean a status of a subject.

sen.j: 皇籍・臣籍とも、主に大日本帝国憲法下において用いられた語であって、現在はほとんど用いられない。
sen.e: At present, both Koseki and Shinseki are rarely used as they were the words mainly employed under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.
At present, both Koseki and Shinseki are rarely used as they were the words mainly employed under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.
At present, both Koseki and Shinseki are rarely used as they were the words mainly employed under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.

sen.j: 皇籍を持つ者が、臣籍にある者との結婚などにより皇籍を離れることを臣籍降下といった。
sen.e: Shinseki koka is the term referring to demotion of members of the Imperial family from nobility to subject by marriage with someone with status of a subject.
Shinseki koka is the term referring to demotion of members of the Imperial family from nobility to subject by marriage with someone with status of a subject.
Shinseki koka is the term referring to demotion of members of the Imperial family from nobility to subject by marriage with someone with status of a subject.

sen.j: 1947年（昭和22年）5月の日本国憲法の施行、および同憲法に基づく皇室典範の施行後は、皇族の身分を離れることを皇籍離脱という。
sen.e: After the enactment of the Japanese Constitution and the Imperial House act drawn up in accordance with the Constitution in May of 1947, the term, Koseki Ridatsu, is used to refer to demotion of members of the Imperial family.

After the enactment of the Japanese Constitution and the Imperial House Act drawn up in accordance with the Constitution in May of 1947, the term Koseki Ridatsu is used to refer to secession from the Imperial Family.
sen.cmt: Imperial House act → Imperial House Act に訂正しました。 Koseki Ridatsu の両端のコンマを削除しました。 Refer to の後の「皇籍離脱」の説明文を、定訳に変更しました。
sen.e: After the enactment of the Japanese Constitution and the Imperial House Act drawn up in accordance with the Constitution in May of 1947, the term Koseki Ridatsu is used to refer to secession from the Imperial Family.
